childhood_context.html:
Childhood: {{BIRTH_YEAR}}-{{CHILDHOOD_END_YEAR}}

The smell of orange shag carpet and cigarette smoke. The feel of a vinyl car seat burning the backs of thighs in August. The taste of Tang, which astronauts supposedly drank, mixed with tap water in a Tupperware pitcher. Growing up in the mid-1970s was tactile in ways that no longer exist—everything had a texture, a temperature, a specific weight in hands.

They were born the year Saigon fell, the year parents watched helicopters lift off embassy rooftops while Gerald Ford tried to convince everyone things were fine. Pet Rocks were the hot gift that Christmas. Adults paid $3.95 for a rock in a box with breathing holes. This is what passed for irony before irony was invented.

At two, Star Wars exploded into existence, and suddenly every kid they knew wanted to be Luke Skywalker or Princess Leia. They had the action figures—the original Kenner ones with the telescoping lightsabers that became collectors' items. Most of them were lost in sandboxes or dogs ate them. At five, Empire Strikes Back revealed that Vader was Luke's father, and some older kid at school ruined it for them before they saw it. Their first spoiler.

Saturday mornings were sacred. They woke up before parents, poured bowls of Cap'n Crunch or Froot Loops, and planted themselves in front of TVs for Schoolhouse Rock between cartoons. 'I'm Just a Bill' taught them more about government than school did. 'Conjunction Junction' made grammar almost fun. They can still sing 'Three Is a Magic Number' from memory.

At six, MTV launched with 'Video Killed the Radio Star,' and suddenly music was something watched. By eleven, every frame of Michael Jackson's 'Thriller' video was known—the transformation, the zombies, the Vincent Price voiceover. Dance moves were practiced in bedroom mirrors. Everyone did.

TV dinners were eaten in their aluminum trays, the ones with the crispy apple dessert in the corner. Hamburger Helper when Mom was tired. Swanson's fried chicken on special occasions. Jiffy Pop on the stovetop, watching the foil dome rise until it looked ready to burst. Hi-C and Kool-Aid were drunk with enough sugar to fuel a small city. Parents smoked inside, car windows rolled up, and somehow they all survived.

At eleven, Challenger exploded. Whole classes were watching—a teacher was going to space. They remember the teachers' faces more than the explosion itself.

generational_identity.html:
The Gen X Generation

Generation X, born between 1965 and 1980. The forgotten middle child. The latchkey generation. The slackers who turned out to be running things while everyone was busy arguing about Boomers and Millennials. There are only 65 million of them—dwarfed by 76 million Boomers above and 72 million Millennials below—which means they've never had the voting power to bend politics their way. They learned to work around systems rather than through them.

They were seven when their parents might have divorced—1982, when divorce rates peaked. Half their friends came from 'broken homes,' which was the term adults used, as if families were vases that got knocked off shelves. They came home to empty houses with a key around their neck, made themselves snacks, watched TV until someone got home. This wasn't neglect; it was how things were. Authority figures lie, institutions fail, trust is earned, not given. They raised themselves, and it shows.

The Cold War was background radiation for their entire childhood. They practiced duck-and-cover drills in elementary school. 'The Day After' aired when they were eight, showing nuclear annihilation in prime time, and parents tried to explain that everything would probably be fine. At fourteen, the Berlin Wall fell. At sixteen, the Soviet Union collapsed. The enemy their entire childhood had been organized around just... disappeared. That particular whiplash never quite resolved.

At {{AGE_AT_911}}, they were {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}} when the towers fell on 9/11. This generation invented the ironic detachment that became the default setting for American culture. They learned to hedge everything with knowing smirks and air quotes because sincerity was dangerous. If they didn't get their hopes up, they couldn't be crushed. If they didn't believe in institutions, they couldn't be betrayed when they failed. 'Whatever' wasn't apathy—it was armor.

They watched Watergate as toddlers, Iran-Contra as preteens, the savings and loan crisis as teenagers. By the time Enron collapsed and the 2008 crash happened, they were so unsurprised it barely registered. Of course the system was rigged. Of course the powerful protected themselves. Of course regular people got screwed. They can still entertain themselves without a screen. That's a superpower now.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

Jaws came out the summer of 1975—a rubber shark that made an entire generation afraid of the ocean. Parents saw it in theaters, probably on a date, definitely before they had children to worry about. 'Bohemian Rhapsody' dropped that same year, six minutes of operatic weirdness that somehow became the greatest rock song ever recorded. Bruce Springsteen released Born to Run, capturing the desperate hunger to escape small towns that would define this generation.

Saturday Night Live premiered on October 11, 1975, four months after they were born. Dan Aykroyd, John Belushi, Gilda Radner, Chevy Chase—not that they'd understand any of it until years later, when reruns were caught and parents' sense of humor was realized came from somewhere. 'Live from New York, it's Saturday Night!' became the sound of staying up past bedtime.

At two, Star Wars was experienced. Even if they were too young to remember seeing it, it was absorbed through merchandise, reruns, and the fact that every kid they'd ever meet had opinions about Han Solo. The Kenner action figures were everywhere—Luke, Leia, Darth Vader, the Millennium Falcon that took up half closets. They learned to play Star Wars before they learned to read.

Childhood TV was The Muppet Show, Happy Days, Laverne & Shirley, Good Times, and The Jeffersons. Diff'rent Strokes asked 'Whatchoo talkin' bout, Willis?' so many times it became a cultural tic. The A-Team blew things up without ever actually hurting anyone. Knight Rider had a talking car, which seemed like the future. They stayed up late to watch M*A*S*H, not fully understanding why adults cared so much about a war that ended before they were born.

At ten, The Breakfast Club came out—five teenagers in Saturday detention, talking about their problems. John Hughes understood something no adult filmmaker had before: that teenagers were actual people with actual inner lives. By twelve, Ferris Bueller was teaching them that life moves pretty fast, and they believed it. Pretty in Pink made Molly Ringwald the face of their generation's romantic confusion.

At sixteen, Nirvana's Nevermind dropped and everything changed. 'Smells Like Teen Spirit' made flannel shirts and unwashed hair into a fashion statement. Grunge wasn't just music—it was permission to be angry and sad and confused all at once. Pearl Jam, Soundgarden, Alice in Chains—Seattle was suddenly the center of the universe. They probably owned Doc Martens. They definitely had opinions about Eddie Vedder.

At nineteen, Kurt Cobain died. April 8, 1994. They remember where they were when they heard. The voice of their generation's alienation, gone at twenty-seven. The MTV News coverage. The makeshift memorials. The sense that something irreplaceable had been lost. They were old enough to grieve, young enough that grief still felt new.

technology.html:
Technology Timeline

The year 1975, Bill Gates and Paul Allen founded Microsoft in Albuquerque, writing BASIC for the Altair 8800—a computer that came as a kit and did almost nothing useful. The personal computer revolution was starting in garages and spare bedrooms, and they'd grow up alongside it, watching technology transform from hobbyist curiosity to the infrastructure of everything.

Childhood was entirely analog. TV channels were changed by walking across the room—or by being the youngest kid, which made them the remote control. Phones were dialed with rotary dials, the plastic clicking back to zero after each number. Things were looked up in encyclopedias, those heavy books that were already outdated by the time they were printed. Card catalogs were used at libraries, flipping through index cards to find books.

At eight, Atari 2600s were gotten, or friends did, and suddenly video games were something played at home instead of at arcades. Space Invaders. Pac-Man. Pitfall. The graphics were blocks and bleeps, but they felt like the future. Joysticks were probably worn out playing Asteroids.

At ten, the Macintosh launched with that famous Super Bowl commercial—the woman throwing a hammer at Big Brother. At eleven, the Nintendo Entertainment System arrived and resurrected the video game industry. Super Mario Bros. changed everything. The Legend of Zelda taught them to save progress on battery-powered cartridges that would eventually die, taking saved games with them.

At twelve, schools got computer labs. Apple IIe machines with green text on black screens. They learned to type on actual typewriters first, then on computers. Oregon Trail was educational, supposedly, though mainly they learned that everyone dies of dysentery. Where in the World Is Carmen Sandiego? taught them geography and how to use encyclopedias to cheat.

At eighteen, the World Wide Web went public. They were in college, or just starting out, when the internet became something regular people could use. At twenty-three, Google launched. At twenty-five, the dot-com boom was in full swing—stock options, foosball tables, companies with no business models valued at billions. At twenty-six, it all collapsed. They learned that 'new economy' was just 'old economy with better marketing.' The skepticism stuck.

They remember life before email, before cell phones, before the internet was everywhere. They know what boredom felt like when they couldn't just scroll something. They can read a physical map, remember phone numbers, entertain themselves without a screen. These are superpowers now, relics of a world that no longer exists. They bridge two eras—the last generation to grow up analog, the first to fully adapt to digital. They're fluent in both languages.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

April 30, 1975: Saigon fell. They were four months old. The last helicopter lifted off from the embassy roof while parents watched on television, ending a war that had defined their entire adult lives. They don't remember it, but they grew up in its aftermath—the veterans who came home to nothing, the POW bracelets, the movies that would start coming when they were teenagers: Apocalypse Now, Platoon, Full Metal Jacket. Vietnam was the wound America couldn't stop picking at.

At five, someone shot Reagan outside the Hilton. They probably watched the footage replayed endlessly on the evening news. At six, AIDS appeared in the headlines, a mysterious disease killing gay men in San Francisco and New York. Nobody understood it yet. The fear and stigma would define the decade.

At four, the Iran hostage crisis began. For 444 days, Americans were held captive—a nightly reminder that American power had limits.

At eight, 241 American service members died in the Beirut barracks bombing. At nine, Michael Jackson's 'Thriller' video terrified and thrilled them in equal measure. At ten, 'We Are the World' tried to solve African famine through celebrity singalong. Their childhood was a strange mix of optimism and violence, morning in America and mourning for real.

At eleven, Challenger exploded. January 28, 1986. They saw it live at school—the moment that would define their generation's loss of innocence.

At fourteen, the Berlin Wall fell. November 9, 1989. People with sledgehammers, champagne, tears. David Hasselhoff on a crane, for reasons nobody ever fully explained. They watched it on TV and tried to understand what it meant. The enemy their entire childhood had been organized around just... wasn't the enemy anymore. At sixteen, the Soviet Union collapsed entirely. The Cold War ended with a whimper, not a bang.

At sixteen, the Gulf War happened—the first war broadcast live on CNN, green night-vision footage that looked like a video game. 'Smart bombs' and 'surgical strikes.' It was supposed to be quick and clean, Vietnam's mistakes corrected. They were young enough to believe some of that.

At {{AGE_AT_911}}, they were {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}} when the towers fell on 9/11. They were at work when the first plane hit. By the time the second plane hit, everyone knew. They watched the towers fall on live television. They spent the rest of the day trying to reach people, confirm that friends in New York were alive, understand something that felt impossible. The world before that morning became a different country.

At thirty-three, the financial system nearly collapsed. Mortgages existed by then, maybe kids, definitely 401(k)s that lost half their value overnight. Friends losing houses were watched. Banks getting bailed out while regular people got nothing were watched. 'Too big to fail' meant the consequences rolled downhill.

At forty-five, COVID. They worked from home, worried about aging parents, explained to their kids why they couldn't see friends. They'd lived through enough crises to know this would pass. That didn't make it easier. It just made them tired.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

The job market of 1997 offered the greatest economic expansion since the 1960s. They graduated college around 1997, give or take, and walked straight into it. The dot-com boom was heating up. Companies were hiring anyone who could spell HTML. Stock options were being handed out like candy. Ping-pong tables in offices. Free snacks. The phrase 'internet millionaire' wasn't ironic yet. Some of them actually became one. Most didn't, but the optimism was intoxicating.

Then March 2000 happened. The NASDAQ peaked at 5,048, then began its long, humiliating slide. Suddenly all those startups with no revenue models were gone. Aeron chairs were being sold at liquidation auctions. Pets.com and Webvan and all the rest became cautionary tales. The old social contract—work hard, stay loyal, retire with a pension—was being shredded in real time. They learned that 'disruptive' often meant 'unprofitable,' that stock options could expire worthless, that the new economy was just the old economy wearing a turtleneck.

If they'd been smart or lucky, they cashed out before the crash. If they hadn't, they went back to regular jobs and tried not to think about what might have been. Either way, they learned something valuable: bubbles pop. Hype dies. Job security became an oxymoron. The fundamentals always win eventually.

This generation pioneered the work-life balance conversation, mostly because they watched their Boomer bosses sacrifice everything—weekends, vacations, families—for companies that would downsize them without hesitation. They saw loyalty repaid with pink slips. They watched middle managers worked to death get replaced by cheaper hires. They were the first generation to openly question whether the corporate ladder was worth climbing. The answer, for many of them: not if the rungs keep disappearing.

At {{AGE_AT_2008_CRISIS}}, the 2008 financial crisis arrived. At thirty-three, the 2008 crash hit. They were mid-career—established enough to have something to lose, young enough that they couldn't just retire early. Colleagues getting laid off were watched. They took on their work to prove they were essential. They learned that companies protect themselves first, always. 'We're all family here' meant nothing when the layoffs came.

Their management style, if they made it to management, tends toward benign neglect. They give people space because that's what they wanted when they were younger. They don't micromanage because they remember hating it. They're deeply skeptical of corporate jargon—'synergy' usually means layoffs, 'restructuring' means someone's getting fired. They've seen too many mission statements that meant nothing.

COVID normalized remote work when they were forty-five, but they'd been figuring out how to work independently since they were latchkey kids heating up pizza rolls after school. They don't need constant supervision. They don't need an office to be productive. Working from home is just the adult version of coming home to an empty house and getting things done anyway.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

Remember passing notes in class? The folded paper triangles, the intricate origami, the risk of getting caught? Remember when getting phone numbers meant something, because calling houses meant potentially talking to parents first? Remember mix tapes—actual cassette tapes—where song selection was a declaration of feelings that couldn't be said out loud?

Gen X grew up in the divorce boom. Their parents, or their friends' parents, or seemingly everyone's parents, split up during the late '70s and '80s. No-fault divorce became standard. Custody arrangements became playground conversation. They learned early that 'forever' was often aspirational, that families reconfigured, that love wasn't enough if everything else fell apart.

This made them cautious. They dated longer before marrying. They cohabitated first to make sure. They'd seen what happened to people who rushed—their parents' friends, their friends' parents, half the adults they knew. Better to wait. Better to be sure. Better to protect themselves than to end up splitting assets and negotiating holidays.

They met partners the old-fashioned way: at parties, through friends, at work, in dorms. By their late twenties, online dating existed—Match.com launched when they were twenty—but it was stigmatized. Admitting they met someone on the internet felt desperate, like they couldn't find someone in real life. 'We met through friends' was the cover story. The stigma faded eventually, but they remember when it was there.

Gen X communication style bridges eras. They wrote actual letters, on paper, with stamps. They learned email in their twenties, texting in their thirties. They can have a phone conversation without anxiety—unlike younger people who treat unexpected calls like ambushes. They remember when being unreachable was normal, when weekends meant they couldn't be found, when leaving the house meant being gone.

If they have kids, they're probably teenagers or young adults now. They watch them navigate social media, influencer culture, dating apps, whatever the current crisis is. They try to give them the independence they had—come home when the streetlights come on, figure it out, they'll be fine—but the world has fewer dark corners where kids can make mistakes unseen. Everything is documented now.

Their friendships have survived decades, divorces, distance. The people who matter have been around since high school or college. They don't need to see someone every week to consider them close. They can pick up exactly where they left off, years later, as if no time has passed. That's what happens when they've known someone for forty years.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

Three major economic crashes hit during their prime earning years. The dot-com crash when they were twenty-five. The 2008 financial crisis when they were thirty-three. Add COVID's economic chaos at forty-five. Mortgage rates hit 18% in the early '80s. The market dropped 40% in 2008. Each one taught them the same lesson: the floor can drop out at any moment, and the people who caused it won't be the ones who pay.

But here's the thing: their timing was actually decent, compared to what came after. They could buy a house in the late '90s or early 2000s for something resembling a reasonable price. Student debt, if they had it, was measured in thousands, not hundreds of thousands. Entry-level jobs paid enough to live on.

The dot-com crash was their first real financial trauma. Paper millionaires becoming paper paupers were watched. Stock options that were supposed to make them rich expired worthless. If they worked at a startup, they probably lost their job. The old social contract—work hard, stay loyal, retire with a pension—was being shredded in real time. They learned that bubbles pop, that 'new paradigm' is usually old hype, that the smart money exits before the dumb money notices.

They recovered. Built something. Then 2008 hit. Mortgages existed by then, maybe kids, definitely 401(k)s that lost half their value overnight. Friends getting foreclosed were watched. Banks getting bailed out—$700 billion for the institutions that caused the crisis—while regular people got nothing were watched. Job security became an oxymoron. 'Too big to fail' meant the consequences flowed downhill, as consequences always do.

Gen X financial psychology is cautious pessimism. They save because they've seen savings evaporate. They invest in index funds because they don't trust stock picks. They keep an emergency fund because emergencies happen—not might happen, will happen. They learned not to trust paper wealth, not to count on employer loyalty, not to assume the system will protect them.

They're in their peak earning years now, which is good because they're squeezed from both directions. Kids need college money—tuition tripled since they graduated. Parents need help—aging is expensive, and Medicare doesn't cover everything. The sandwich generation metaphor isn't a metaphor; they're literally paying in two directions while trying to save for a retirement that may or may not be possible.

Social Security will probably exist when they hit sixty-seven. Their 401(k) might be enough. The math works on paper. But paper is what burned in 2008, and they've learned to plan for the best while expecting the worst.

blind_spots.html:
Generational Blind Spots

This generation's independence is both their superpower and their liability. They figured things out on their own because they had to—empty house after school, no parents around, make themselves a snack and do homework. That self-reliance got them through. But it also means they don't ask for help when they should. They suffer unnecessarily. They assume everyone can figure it out alone, because they did. They can't always. Neither could they, really.

The ironic detachment that served them well at twenty becomes a prison at fifty. They learned not to care too visibly because caring made them vulnerable. But perpetual irony is exhausting. The knowing smirk, the air quotes, the reflexive 'whatever'—at some point, they have to actually commit to something. Caring is risky. It's also the only thing that matters.

They dismiss younger generations too quickly. Yes, Millennials complain about avocado toast. Yes, Gen Z communicates in ways that mystify them. But younger generations are facing problems Gen X didn't: student debt in the six figures, housing costs that doubled and tripled, a job market that treats them as infinitely replaceable. Gen X's 'I figured it out, so can they' ignores that the game changed after they learned the rules. The bootstraps cost more than the boots now.

Their skepticism can curdle into cynicism. Not everything is corrupt. Not everyone in power is lying. Sometimes systems work, sometimes people mean well, sometimes optimism is warranted. Assuming the worst protects them from disappointment, but it also prevents them from pushing for things to improve. Cynicism is safe. It's also passive. It's also, at this point, a little boring.

They underestimate how much technology has changed things. They adapted to smartphones and social media, but they don't feel their effects the way people who grew up immersed feel them. The loneliness epidemic, the mental health crisis, the way algorithms shape reality—these hit different when they've never known anything else. Their 'just put down the phone' advice isn't wrong. It's also insufficient.

And maybe the deepest blind spot: they got lucky on timing and they don't fully acknowledge it. They bought houses before prices tripled. They started careers when entry-level jobs paid living wages. They accumulated assets when accumulation was possible. Not everyone can bootstrap their way to stability when the ladder's been pulled up. Acknowledging luck isn't diminishing their hard work. It's understanding why hard work doesn't work the same way anymore.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Their 20s (1995-2005): They graduated into a decent economy—maybe the last decent economy, in retrospect. Jobs existed. The dot-com boom was heating up. If they had any computer skills, companies threw money at them. Stock options! Foosball! The word 'disruptive' wasn't ironic yet. They moved to cities, dated people, figured out what they wanted from life. Some of them got rich during the boom. Most didn't, but the possibility felt real. Then 2000 hit and the bubble burst, teaching them that paper wealth can become paper losses overnight. They recovered. They adapted. That's what they do.

Their 30s (2005-2015): They probably settled down, or decided not to. Marriage, kids, mortgage—the traditional markers happened for some of them. Others chose different paths. By their mid-thirties, they'd built something: career stability, savings, maybe a house. Then 2008 hit when they were thirty-three. The financial crisis didn't just damage their 401(k); it damaged their faith that planning could protect them. Friends losing houses were watched. Banks getting bailed out were watched. They rebuilt anyway, because that's the only option.

Their 40s (2015-2025): The recovery decade. They rebuilt what 2008 damaged—retirement accounts, confidence, the tentative belief that the ground might stay solid. Their kids, if they had them, were growing up. Their parents were aging. They became the responsible adult in the room, whether they wanted that job or not. Career-wise, they either made it to management or realized they didn't want to—the corporate ladder looked different from halfway up. COVID hit when they were forty-five, sending everyone home and reshuffling everything again. Another crisis. Another adaptation.

Their 50s (2025-2035): They're here now, or approaching it. Peak earning years. Peak responsibility. Their kids are launching into a world harder than the one they entered—housing costs double what they paid, job markets that treat workers as disposable. Their parents need more help, and help is expensive. They're thinking about retirement, not sure they can afford it, not sure what they'd do with themselves. They've lived through enough disruption to know more is coming. The question isn't whether the next crisis happens, but what form it takes.

Their 60s and beyond (2035+): Retirement, maybe. Or semi-retirement—working less, choosing projects, staying engaged because idleness was never their style. Social Security will probably exist; whether it's enough is another question. Their health matters more now than it did. The friends who matter have been around for decades. They've earned the right to not care what people think, to say no to things that don't serve them, to spend their time on what actually matters. They survived recessions, pandemics, wars, technological revolutions. Whatever comes next, they'll probably survive that too. They always have.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

{{BIRTH_YEAR_COHORT}} people were born in the US in 1975. Generation X as a whole numbers about 65 million Americans—the smallest generation wedged between two behemoths. 76 million Boomers had the numbers to shape policy. 72 million Millennials had the numbers to shape culture. Gen X had... the ability to be overlooked, which is fine by them. Attention was never the point.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964): Boomers got affordable college—Gen X got student loans. Boomers got pensions—Gen X got 401(k)s and 'personal responsibility.' Boomers bought houses for two years' salary—Gen X watched prices triple. Boomers had Woodstock—Gen X had Lollapalooza, which was self-consciously trying to be Woodstock. Boomers believed they could change the world. Gen X believed they could survive it. Both were half right.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996): Gen X is the older sibling Millennials resent. Gen X bought houses before prices went insane. Gen X started careers when entry-level jobs still paid living wages. Millennials graduated into the 2008 crater; Gen X hit it mid-career. The difference isn't character—it's timing. Millennials expect institutions to work; Gen X expects them to fail. Both positions have evidence on their side.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): Gen X is analogs in a digital world. Gen Z has never known life without the internet; Gen X remembers rotary phones. Gen Z grew up with social media shaping their identity from childhood; Gen X formed their identity first, then got Facebook in their thirties. Gen Z is anxious in ways that mystify Gen X. Gen X is dismissive in ways that frustrate Gen Z. Neither is entirely wrong about the other.

Gen X life expectancy is around 76-78 years, though substance-related health challenges—suicide, overdose, alcoholism—have hit Gen X harder than previous generations. The ironic detachment has a cost. Independence can become isolation. Skepticism can curdle into nihilism. Their greatest strength is also their vulnerability: they're so good at not needing anyone that they forget they actually do.

They didn't complain about it—they just did the work. That's their legacy: competence without fanfare. But they've also built lives with less institutional support than any generation before them. No pensions, no job security, no guarantee that the rules would stay stable. They adapted without complaint, raised kids while working, cared for aging parents while saving for uncertain retirements. They can still entertain themselves without a screen. That's a superpower now.

year_events: Vietnam War ended with the fall of Saigon
Microsoft was founded by Bill Gates and Paul Allen
Saturday Night Live premiered on NBC
Jaws became the first summer blockbuster
One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest won Best Picture
